#### Section 3: Quantum mechanical model for absorption: the particle in a box
There are several models one can use to predict the electronic
transitions and absorption properties of relatively simple absorbers
like organic dyes. The simplest---though it is not simple to any
first-time learner---is the **particle-in-a-box** model. The most common
type of particle-in-a-box is an electron in an energy well with
infinitely hard side walls. Inside the well, the potential energy is
zero. Beyond the walls, the potential energy is infinite. Imagine that
an electron is placed in the well. Remember our discussion of photons as
both particles and waves? It turns out that *every* object can be
treated as both a particle and a wave. That is, even solid, macroscopic
objects have wavelike properties. However, for objects of appreciable
mass, the wavelength is miniscule and the object can be treated as a
particle only. Thus, the wavelike properties of matter typically only
manifest for electrons, protons, atoms, and very small molecules.

The behavior of an electron inside the box can be described by a
**wavefunction**, which is a solution to the **Schrödinger equation**

(Equation 8.2) $$-\frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\frac{d^2\psi(x)}{dx^2}=E\psi(x)$$

where $\hbar$ is Planck's constant divided by 2$\pi$, $m$ is the mass of
the particle (the electron in this case), $\psi(x)$ is the wave
function, $x$ is the horizontal position variable along the box, and
$\frac{d^2\psi(x)}{dx^2}$ is the second derivative of the wave function
with respect to the position.[^8.3.1] The Schrödinger equation is an example
of a **differential equation**, which is a function that is related to
its own derivative. While there are whole courses in "diff-eq" that you
will probably take later in your studies, we can get most of the way
there just by looking at the equation with the sparest knowledge of
first-semester or AP calculus. The question is, what function has the
same form as its second derivative? The answer is sine and cosine
functions! After some guessing and checking, one can come up with the
following

(Equation 8.3) $$\psi_n(x)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{L}}\sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}}$$

where the index $n$ is an integer $\geq$ 1. Plugging this solution back
into equation (8.2), we get an expression for the energy

(Equation 8.4) $$E_n=\frac{h^2n^2}{8mL^2}$$

where $E_n$ is the energy of the $n^{th}$ energy level. The shapes of
the wave functions and the energies of the electrons occupying these
states only have physical meaning in the most contrived, idealized
scenarios. Nevertheless, wave functions can be obtained for a number of
potentials, such as spherical ones for atoms.

termed the **ground state**, $n=2$, termed the **first excited state**,
and $n=3$, the **second excited state**.[^8.3.2] In these diagrams, the wave
function $\psi(x)$ is the **probability amplitude**; it shows the shape
of the wave function, and in particular the phases (i.e., above and
below an imaginary horizontal line separating the "positive" and
"negative" regions of the function). The square of this function,
$|\psi(x)|^2$, is the **probability density**, which is positive (above
the horizontal line) everywhere. That is, the function which shows where
you are most likely to find the electron within the box. This function
integrates to 1, since that is the probability of finding the electron
somewhere in the box.

good for? It turns out that the particle-in-a-box model is most useful

of a molecule or a solid. In some (idealized) cases, it is even possible
to get a number that's in the right ballpark of the correct value for a

the fact that the electrons are not truly **delocalized**. That is, in a
real molecule---not the fake construct of a box with infinite
walls---the electrons are not free to occupy any of the length of the
"box" defined by the $\pi$ system.

### 8.3.2. Quantum dots

A quantum dot is a clever nickname for a **semiconductor nanocrystal**.
The moniker "dot" emphasizes the quantization of the energy levels. Just
like the particle in a box, a quantum dot has **quantized**---can only
take on a predefined set of energies---absorption and emission behavior.
Quantum dots can be made of any direct-bandgap semiconductor, but are
often metal chalcogenides, including cadmium selenide (CdSe), cadmium
telluride (CdTe), and lead sulfide (PbS). However, any small
semiconductor particle with quantized energy levels will exhibit
quantum-dot-like behavior. Small platelets of graphene will even
qualify: **graphene quantum dots**.

The energy of absorption and emission in a quantum dot follows the same
qualitative trend as in the particle-in-a-box model: the smaller the
dot, the more confined the electron, the larger the bandgap, and thus
the bluer (higher energy!) the absorption and emission. It is common to
see pretty photographs of fluorescent quantum dots like the drawing in
Figure (8.9), which emphasizes the relationship between particle size
and band gap.

#### Section 2: Scattering, absorption, and nothing
When a photon strikes an object, three things can happen:
**scattering**, **absorption**, and **nothing**. Which of these
eventualities occurs depends on the size, shape, atomic composition, and
various idiosyncracies of the chunk of matter under consideration.

### 8.2.1. Scattering

Scattering is the process of absorption and re-emission of a photon in
rapid succession. In fact, most of the photons that arrive at our
retinas have been scattered by the objects we perceive in our visual
field. Absorption and re-emission occurs by transient[^8.2.1] polarization
of the electron cloud of the atoms that make up an object; when the
electron cloud returns to its unpolarized equilibrium, a photon is
re-emitted. This re-emitted photon is known as the **scattered photon**.

#### Elastic and inelastic scattering

The energy of the scattered photon is either greater than, less than, or
equal to the energy of the incident photon. In the case where the
scattered photon has the same energy as that of the incident photon, the
scattering process is deemed **elastic** or **Rayleigh** scattering.
That is, energy was neither absorbed by the material nor transferred to
the photon as a result of the collision. When the energy is greater than
or less than that of the incident photon, the process is said to be
**inelastic** or **Raman** scattering. That is, energy is either
absorbed by the material or transferred from the material to the photon.
A schematic diagram of the two scattering processes is shown in Figure
(8.2).

(Figure 8.2) 
>>>image(scattering.png.0)

Inelastic scattering---the type of scattering where energy is absorbed
by the material as a result of the collision---is by far the more common
type. In this case, the energy of the scattered photon is less than the
energy of the incident photon (longer wavelength). The "missing" energy
from the incident photon often goes into raising the vibrational energy
of the scatterer. That is, energy gets transferred from the incident
photon to the scatterer, which is initially in a low-energy vibrational
state. The scatterer absorbs some of this energy, knocking it up to a
higher energy vibrational state (i.e., vibrating at a higher frequency).
The downward shift in the energy of the scattered photon with respect to
that of the incident photon is called a **Stokes shift**, which just
means that the scattered photon has less energy than the incident
photon. You may also see the word **red shift** or the super jargony
word ***bathochromic* shift**.

#### Vibrational spectroscopy: Infrared and Raman

Sometimes, a scatterer is already in a higher (excited) vibrational
state, and in the process of collision with the incoming photon, this
extra energy is transferred to the scattered photon. The scattered
photon thus has increased energy (shorter wavelength) compared to the
energy of the incident photon. The shift in wavelength of the scattered
photon relative to the incident photon is called an **anti-Stokes**
shift, a **blue shift**, or a ***hypsochromic* shift**. Vibrational
transitions, which are are usually in the infrared region of the EM
spectrum, can be observed directly by infrared absorption
spectroscopy[^8.2.2] or indirectly upon irradiation with a laser of a
visible wavelength, by **Raman spectroscopy**. In this modality, the
energy of the vibrational transition is equal to the difference in
energy between the incident and scattered light.[^8.2.3]

The differences in energy between incident and scattered or emitted
photons is the basis of the field of **spectroscopy**. It is often
possible to reveal something about the construction of molecules and the
composition of matter by analyzing the *spectra* produced by
light-matter interactions. These spectra can act as fingerprints unique
to the interaction taking place, and like detectives at the scene of a
crime, we can use spectroscopy help identify the matter of interest. We
will touch on electronic absorption (ultraviolet-visible) and
fluorescence spectroscopy in later sections in this chapter.

### 8.2.2. Absorption due to the movement of electrons

As we hinted in the discussion of scattering, it is common for some or
all of the energy of an incident photon to be absorbed by the material
or molecule. We touched on changes in vibrational energy levels that can
occur upon absorption, but such differences usually take place in the
infrared spectrum. For optoelectronic applications (e.g., solar cells
and display panels), we are often more interested in those that occur in
the visible range of the EM spectrum. The molecular basis for visible
absorption usually involves promotion of electrons from the **conduction
band** or **bonding orbitals** to the **valence band** or **antibonding
orbitals**. These transitions are interesting because they can indicate
chemical activity such as bond breakage or photon-driven charge
separation in solar cells. In Figure (8.3), we see a diagram of the band
energies for a generic material that absorbs light in the visible region
of the EM spectrum (i.e., a dye molecule, a semiconductor, or a quantum
dot).

(Figure 8.3) 
>>>image(orbitals.png.0)

You might ask why, if the band gap energy has a specific value (say, 2.5
electron volts), the absorption spectrum is a broad hump and not a sharp
vertical line. Indeed, for a completely isolated, single molecule at a
temperature of absolute zero, one might obtain a single vertical line.
The reason this does not happen in the real world is that the gap
between the valence and conduction bands is a measure of the gap between
the **frontiers** or **edges** of these bands. When a molecule is in
solution and in van der Waals contact with nearby molecules, the energy
levels become blurry. That is, there are many energy states above and
below these levels to and from which electrons can be excited by an
incoming photon. The function that describes the distribution of energy
levels is called the **density of states**. It is this interplay of
light and electronic energy levels---combined with the phenomena in
scattering---that gives rise to the perception of color.

### 8.2.3. Emission: Fluorescence and Phosphorescence

Suppose a molecule absorbs a photon, and an electron that was initially
in the ground state (say at the valence band edge) gets promoted to a
higher energy level (say the conduction band edge). The potential energy
of the electron is now substantially greater than it was before, and
this is an unstable situation. The electron will tend to return to its
ground state, and can do so in a number of ways. For example, it can
collide with some other molecules, which take on some of the energy as
translational motion, and the electron eventually makes its way back to
the valence band. This process is called **non-radiative
recombination**[^8.2.4]. Alternatively, the electron can transfer its energy
to another molecule, whose electron gets promoted, while the electron of
the original molecule returns to its ground state. This type of energy
transfer can be mediated by a photon---i.e., emitted by the first
molecule and absorbed by the second---or it can occur through space,
without the emission of a photon. When the non-photon process occurs, it
is called **Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET)**, and tends to
occur when the emission spectrum of the first molecule overlaps with the
absorption spectrum of the second. Finally, the excited electron may
decay to the ground state by emitting a photon similar, but not usually
identical,[^8.2.5] to the band gap in two related processes known as
*fluorescence* and *phosphorescence*.

#### Photoluminescence I: Fluorescence

If you have ever been in a room with a black light (i.e., near-visible,
UV-A light) or pointed one at various objects to see if anything glows,
that glowing is a type of **photoluminescence**[^8.2.6] called
**fluorescence**. In general, fluorescence occurs when high-energy light
is absorbed and re-emitted by a molecule or material as lower-energy
light. To see why this is, consider Figure (8.4) shown below.

(Figure 8.4) 
>>>image(thermalization.png.0)

The band gap has a specific energy and it is true that photons with
energies *below* the band gap do not get absorbed. However, we know that
photons with energies *above* than the band gap get absorbed all the
time. When an electron gets excited by such a high-energy photon, where
does it go? The answer is that it gets promoted to one of the energy
levels above the band edge with a probability based on the **density of
states**.[^8.2.7] Once the electron is in this higher-energy state, it
quickly transitions down to the band edge by releasing its energy into
the bulk material (or solution) as heat. This process, known as
**thermalization**, ensures that the starting point for every
fluorescent process starts with the electron at the bottom of the
conduction band. While these electrons may return to the energy level
exactly at the edge of the valence band, it is more likely that they too
will find a band with a lower energy than the band edge. Again, this
process is determined by the density of states, this time below the band
edge. These processes ensure that the energy of the absorption spectrum
for a molecule or material is centered in a range higher than that of
the fluorescence spectrum.

#### Photoluminescence II: Phosphorescence

The day I wrote this sentence, I helped my three-year-old daughter put
constellations of glow-in-the-dark stars on the ceiling of her bedroom.
At first, the glow emitted by glow-in-the-dark stickers, plastic, and
paint seems like it might be fluorescent. However, fluorescent items
stop glowing as soon as we turn off the excitation sources, whereas
glow-in-the-dark materials stay lit for several minutes or even hours.
This long-lasting glow is indicative of a process known as
**phosphorescence**. Phosphorescence occurs when the **spin** of an
excited electron changes sign (i.e., from "up" to "down" or vice versa).
Such an electron enters a new manifold of energy states in a process
called **intersystem crossing**. From this new manifold of energy
states, the spin of the electron must go back to its original spin in
order to transition back down to its original ground state. This
transition is quantum mechanically "forbidden." It still happens, but
with a lower probability and thus it takes a long time. Hence why the
stars glow long after the lamp is turned off.

### 8.2.4. Perception of color

Before we begin, it is important to be aware of the limitations of our

perfect "eyeball spectrometer" (though it is quite good in many
circumstances). In fact, we have three types of color receptive **cone
cells** in our retinas (unless you have some form of colorblindness).

### 8.3.1. Organic dyes and the color of carrots

The particle-in-a-box model can first seem very obscure. What it is it
good for? It turns out that the particle-in-a-box model is most useful
in determining energy *differences* between states. Often, what we care
about most are the gaps between the valence band and the conduction band
of a molecule or a solid. In some (idealized) cases, it is even possible
to get a number that's in the right ballpark of the correct value for a
physical system. Consider the structure of $\beta$-carotene, below
(Figure (8.8)).

(Figure 8.8) 
>>>image(betacarotene.png.0)

$\beta$-Carotene is the structure most commonly associated with the
orange color of carrots, though in pure form it is more red than orange.
The most striking structural feature of $\beta$-carotene is its long
conjugated core (that is, alternating double and single bonds). Such a
structure gives rise to absorption in the visible region of the
electromagnetic spectrum.[^8.3.3] It is actually possible to use the
particle-in-a-box model to predict that $\beta$-carotene absorbs in the
visible region of the spectrum. Furthermore, if we are a little loose
with some of the parameters, we can get it to appear orange.

To start out, we need to know the approximate length of the
$\pi$-conjugated **chromophore**[^8.3.4] and the number of electrons in it.
Let's say a good approximation is 18.5 Å. Looking at the structure in
Figure (8.8), we see that there are 22 carbon atoms involved in the
$\pi$ system. From general chemistry, we know that some number of
**atomic orbitals** give rise to the same number of **molecular
orbitals**. So, we will expect to have 22 total molecular orbitals. An
orbital is a place where electrons live, and it can be defined
mathematically by a wave function, $\psi(x)$. As you may also remember,
each bonding molecular orbital gets two electrons, so the first 11 wave
functions starting with the lowest energy---representing the 11
**bonding orbitals** of $\beta$-carotene---are filled, while the top 11
wave functions---representing the **antibonding orbitals** are empty.
The bonding orbitals can be treated as the valence band, and the
antibonding orbitals can be treated as the conduction band. The **band
gap** is defined as the difference in energy between the **highest
occupied molecular orbital (HOMO)** (i.e., the valence band edge) and
the **lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO)** (i.e., the conduction
band edge). Convince yourself that the difference in energy is given by
the following equation:

(Equation 8.5) $$\Delta E = (n_f^2 - n_i^2)\frac{h^2}{8 m L^2}$$

where $n_i$ is the initial state and $n_f$ is the final state. When the
molecule absorbs a photon, the electron is promoted from $n_i$ to $n_f$.
If these two states correspond to the band edges, then $n_i=11$ and
$n_f=12$. So,

$$\Delta E = (12^2 - 11^2)\frac{h^2}{8 m L^2}$$

$$\Delta E = \frac{23h^2}{8 m L^2}$$

$$\Delta E = \frac{23 \times (6.6 \times 10^{-34} \, \text{Js})^2}{8 (9.1 \times 10^{-31} \, \text{kg})(1.85 \times 10^{-9} \, \text{m})^2}$$

$$\Delta E = \frac{hc}{490 \, \text{nm}}$$


The real bandgap of $\beta$-carotene is closer to 470 nm, but we should
be surprised that this super simple model got as close as it did. After
all, 18.5 Å is not quite the length of the $\pi$ system, however, we
also ignored all of the electrostatic effects of the protons, the fact
that these molecules are twisting and dancing all over the place, and
the fact that the electrons are not truly **delocalized**. That is, in a
real molecule---not the fake construct of a box with infinite
walls---the electrons are not free to occupy any of the length of the
"box" defined by the $\pi$ system.

### 8.3.2. Quantum dots

A quantum dot is a clever nickname for a **semiconductor nanocrystal**.
The moniker "dot" emphasizes the quantization of the energy levels. Just
like the particle in a box, a quantum dot has **quantized**---can only
take on a predefined set of energies---absorption and emission behavior.
Quantum dots can be made of any direct-bandgap semiconductor, but are
often metal chalcogenides, including cadmium selenide (CdSe), cadmium
telluride (CdTe), and lead sulfide (PbS). However, any small
semiconductor particle with quantized energy levels will exhibit
quantum-dot-like behavior. Small platelets of graphene will even
qualify: **graphene quantum dots**.

The energy of absorption and emission in a quantum dot follows the same
qualitative trend as in the particle-in-a-box model: the smaller the
dot, the more confined the electron, the larger the bandgap, and thus
the bluer (higher energy!) the absorption and emission. It is common to
see pretty photographs of fluorescent quantum dots like the drawing in
Figure (8.9), which emphasizes the relationship between particle size
and band gap.

(Figure 8.9) 
>>>image(quantum dot.png.0)

The energy of emission of a quantum dot can be predicted by calculating
its band gap, as determined by

(Equation 8.6)
$$E_{QD} = E_{bulk} + \frac{\hbar^2\pi^2}{2a^2} (\frac{1}{m_e} + \frac{1}{m_h}) - \frac{1.8e^2}{4\pi\epsilon\epsilon_0a}$$

where the first term is the energy of the bandgap of the bulk
semiconductor (i.e., a block of the material of macroscopic extent), the
second term is due to size confinement (i.e., the particle-in-a-box
energy), and the third term is the Coulombic attraction between the
electron and the hole. $\hbar$ is Planck's constant divided by 2$\pi$,
and $a$ is the radius of the quantum dot. The band gap of the quantum
dot is greater than that of the bulk semiconductor by an amount related
to the particle-in-a-box energy (notice the similarity of the second
term of equation (8.6) to that of equation (8.5)). In this case, $m_e$
and $m_h$ are the masses of the electron and hole.[^8.3.5] Finally, the
energy of the bandgap of the quantum dot is reduced by the (favorable)
attraction between the electron and hole. In fact, the final term in
equation (8.6) looks a lot like Coulomb's law, equation (2.1).

#### Section 1: Properties of light
Everything you see around you is ultimately the result of light waves
interacting with molecular structures, nanostructures, and
surfaces---i.e., **light-matter interactions**. These light waves engage
the matter in various ways, and some of them are conveyed back to you to
create an image on your retina. The way that light waves interact with
atoms and molecules, and then travel to reach your retina, involves
several different processes. Since visible light occupies the range of
wavelengths from around 400-700 nm, these processes are by definition
mediated on the nanoscale. Thus, the atomic and molecular structure,
along with the nanoscale geometry of matter, determine what happens when
a **photon** of light strikes the object.[^8.1.1] For example, the photon
may be absorbed and its energy could be transferred to an electron. In
another scenario, the photon may cause the conduction electrons in a
solid to be briefly polarized and then return to equilibrium by
re-emitting a photon. Alternatively, nothing may happen. These
interactions between light and matter are responsible for much of our
observed, day-to-day experience. Moreover, they also enable myriad
applications, from solar cells to displays, which will be discussed in
the next chapter. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/0mnYMJQko-0)

Electromagnetic radiation consists of propagating, oscillating
**electric** and **magnetic fields** oriented 90 $^{\circ}$ to each
other. The **electromagnetic spectrum**, Figure (8.1), is a linear range
of energies, which are often expressed in terms of either frequency or
wavelength, through the following relationships, expressed in equation
[\[fig:EM spectrum\]](#fig:EM spectrum){reference-type="eqref"
reference="fig:EM spectrum"}.

(Figure 8.1) 
>>>image(EM spectrum.png.0)

(Equation 8.1) $$E=h\nu=\frac{hc}{\lambda}$$

Here, $E$ is the energy, expressed in joules (J) or electron volts
(eV),[^8.1.2] $h$ is Planck's constant
(6.626$\times10^{-34}\text{ J s or J per Hz}$, $\nu$ is the frequency in
Hz (s$^{-1}$), $c$ is the speed of light in a vacuum, and $\lambda$ is
the wavelength.

### 8.1.1. Wave-particle duality

Electromagnetic waves have properties of both waves and particles. For
example, light diffracts like a wave, meaning that it bends around
corners and interferes with itself when passing through slits. However,
it also reflects off of objects like the way that billiard balls bounce
off of objects. Moreover, light is made of up small, quantized bits of
energy. These single particles of light are called **photons**[^8.1.3]
Wave-particle duality emerges when considering the fact that single
photons can also interfere with themselves. This property was
demonstrated using a now classic setup called **Young's double-slit
experiment**. When shining a light through two closely spaced slits
(openings) to a projection screen, one obtains a diffraction pattern of
many minima and maxima in light intensity.[^8.1.4] Later, it was determined
that the same pattern is obtained even when the source only emits a
single photon at a time (which produces a single blip on the screen or
detector) if the photon counts are all added up after the experiment
runs for a while. So, a single photon is passing through the slits,
interfering with itself, and yet producing a single spot on the
detector! Diffraction is also the basis of **X-ray crystallography**,
discussed in Chapter 14.

### 8.1.2. Types of EM radiation

Visible light comprises only a small region of the EM spectrum, from
400-700 nm. Smaller wavelengths---higher energies---are ultraviolet,
then X-rays, then gamma ($\gamma$) rays. Larger wavelengths---lower
energies---are infrared (IR), then microwaves, then radio waves (Figure
(8.1)). Each range of wavelengths interacts with matter at a different
scale. For example, gamma rays are associated with nuclear reactions.
X-rays are associated with nuclear reactions and the differences in
energy between electrons at the surface of an atom and those at the
core. Ultraviolet radiation is absorbed by electrons involved in bonds
extending across a few atoms, while visible light is absorbed by
electrons delocalized across many atoms. IR radiation can excite
vibrational and rotational motions in molecules, while microwaves can
excite motion in molecules having permanent dipoles. Radio waves
interact with larger (centimeter to meter scale) metallic structures.
The use of EM radiation to probe aspects of the structure of
matter---i.e., **spectroscopy**---is covered in Chapter 14.

#### Section 2: Scattering, absorption, and nothing
When a photon strikes an object, three things can happen:
**scattering**, **absorption**, and **nothing**. Which of these
eventualities occurs depends on the size, shape, atomic composition, and
various idiosyncracies of the chunk of matter under consideration.

### 8.2.1. Scattering

Scattering is the process of absorption and re-emission of a photon in
rapid succession. In fact, most of the photons that arrive at our
retinas have been scattered by the objects we perceive in our visual
field. Absorption and re-emission occurs by transient[^8.2.1] polarization
of the electron cloud of the atoms that make up an object; when the
electron cloud returns to its unpolarized equilibrium, a photon is
re-emitted. This re-emitted photon is known as the **scattered photon**.

#### Elastic and inelastic scattering

The energy of the scattered photon is either greater than, less than, or
equal to the energy of the incident photon. In the case where the
scattered photon has the same energy as that of the incident photon, the
scattering process is deemed **elastic** or **Rayleigh** scattering.
That is, energy was neither absorbed by the material nor transferred to
the photon as a result of the collision. When the energy is greater than
or less than that of the incident photon, the process is said to be
**inelastic** or **Raman** scattering. That is, energy is either
absorbed by the material or transferred from the material to the photon.
A schematic diagram of the two scattering processes is shown in Figure
(8.2).

(Figure 8.2) 
>>>image(scattering.png.0)

Inelastic scattering---the type of scattering where energy is absorbed
by the material as a result of the collision---is by far the more common
type. In this case, the energy of the scattered photon is less than the
energy of the incident photon (longer wavelength). The "missing" energy
from the incident photon often goes into raising the vibrational energy
of the scatterer. That is, energy gets transferred from the incident
photon to the scatterer, which is initially in a low-energy vibrational
state. The scatterer absorbs some of this energy, knocking it up to a
higher energy vibrational state (i.e., vibrating at a higher frequency).
The downward shift in the energy of the scattered photon with respect to
that of the incident photon is called a **Stokes shift**, which just
means that the scattered photon has less energy than the incident
photon. You may also see the word **red shift** or the super jargony
word ***bathochromic* shift**.

#### Vibrational spectroscopy: Infrared and Raman

Sometimes, a scatterer is already in a higher (excited) vibrational
state, and in the process of collision with the incoming photon, this
extra energy is transferred to the scattered photon. The scattered
photon thus has increased energy (shorter wavelength) compared to the
energy of the incident photon. The shift in wavelength of the scattered
photon relative to the incident photon is called an **anti-Stokes**
shift, a **blue shift**, or a ***hypsochromic* shift**. Vibrational
transitions, which are are usually in the infrared region of the EM
spectrum, can be observed directly by infrared absorption
spectroscopy[^8.2.2] or indirectly upon irradiation with a laser of a
visible wavelength, by **Raman spectroscopy**. In this modality, the
energy of the vibrational transition is equal to the difference in
energy between the incident and scattered light.[^8.2.3]

The differences in energy between incident and scattered or emitted
photons is the basis of the field of **spectroscopy**. It is often
possible to reveal something about the construction of molecules and the
composition of matter by analyzing the *spectra* produced by
light-matter interactions. These spectra can act as fingerprints unique
to the interaction taking place, and like detectives at the scene of a
crime, we can use spectroscopy help identify the matter of interest. We
will touch on electronic absorption (ultraviolet-visible) and
fluorescence spectroscopy in later sections in this chapter.

### 8.2.2. Absorption due to the movement of electrons

As we hinted in the discussion of scattering, it is common for some or
all of the energy of an incident photon to be absorbed by the material
or molecule. We touched on changes in vibrational energy levels that can
occur upon absorption, but such differences usually take place in the
infrared spectrum. For optoelectronic applications (e.g., solar cells
and display panels), we are often more interested in those that occur in
the visible range of the EM spectrum. The molecular basis for visible
absorption usually involves promotion of electrons from the **conduction
band** or **bonding orbitals** to the **valence band** or **antibonding
orbitals**. These transitions are interesting because they can indicate
chemical activity such as bond breakage or photon-driven charge
separation in solar cells. In Figure (8.3), we see a diagram of the band
energies for a generic material that absorbs light in the visible region
of the EM spectrum (i.e., a dye molecule, a semiconductor, or a quantum
dot).

(Figure 8.3) 
>>>image(orbitals.png.0)

You might ask why, if the band gap energy has a specific value (say, 2.5
electron volts), the absorption spectrum is a broad hump and not a sharp
vertical line. Indeed, for a completely isolated, single molecule at a
temperature of absolute zero, one might obtain a single vertical line.
The reason this does not happen in the real world is that the gap
between the valence and conduction bands is a measure of the gap between
the **frontiers** or **edges** of these bands. When a molecule is in
solution and in van der Waals contact with nearby molecules, the energy
levels become blurry. That is, there are many energy states above and
below these levels to and from which electrons can be excited by an
incoming photon. The function that describes the distribution of energy
levels is called the **density of states**. It is this interplay of
light and electronic energy levels---combined with the phenomena in
scattering---that gives rise to the perception of color.

### 8.2.3. Emission: Fluorescence and Phosphorescence

Suppose a molecule absorbs a photon, and an electron that was initially
in the ground state (say at the valence band edge) gets promoted to a
higher energy level (say the conduction band edge). The potential energy
of the electron is now substantially greater than it was before, and
this is an unstable situation. The electron will tend to return to its
ground state, and can do so in a number of ways. For example, it can
collide with some other molecules, which take on some of the energy as
translational motion, and the electron eventually makes its way back to
the valence band. This process is called **non-radiative
recombination**[^8.2.4]. Alternatively, the electron can transfer its energy
to another molecule, whose electron gets promoted, while the electron of
the original molecule returns to its ground state. This type of energy
transfer can be mediated by a photon---i.e., emitted by the first
molecule and absorbed by the second---or it can occur through space,
without the emission of a photon. When the non-photon process occurs, it
is called **Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET)**, and tends to
occur when the emission spectrum of the first molecule overlaps with the
absorption spectrum of the second. Finally, the excited electron may
decay to the ground state by emitting a photon similar, but not usually
identical,[^8.2.5] to the band gap in two related processes known as
*fluorescence* and *phosphorescence*.

#### Photoluminescence I: Fluorescence

If you have ever been in a room with a black light (i.e., near-visible,
UV-A light) or pointed one at various objects to see if anything glows,
that glowing is a type of **photoluminescence**[^8.2.6] called
**fluorescence**. In general, fluorescence occurs when high-energy light
is absorbed and re-emitted by a molecule or material as lower-energy
light. To see why this is, consider Figure (8.4) shown below.

(Figure 8.4) 
>>>image(thermalization.png.0)

The band gap has a specific energy and it is true that photons with
energies *below* the band gap do not get absorbed. However, we know that
photons with energies *above* than the band gap get absorbed all the
time. When an electron gets excited by such a high-energy photon, where
does it go? The answer is that it gets promoted to one of the energy
levels above the band edge with a probability based on the **density of
states**.[^8.2.7] Once the electron is in this higher-energy state, it
quickly transitions down to the band edge by releasing its energy into
the bulk material (or solution) as heat. This process, known as
**thermalization**, ensures that the starting point for every
fluorescent process starts with the electron at the bottom of the
conduction band. While these electrons may return to the energy level
exactly at the edge of the valence band, it is more likely that they too
will find a band with a lower energy than the band edge. Again, this
process is determined by the density of states, this time below the band
edge. These processes ensure that the energy of the absorption spectrum
for a molecule or material is centered in a range higher than that of
the fluorescence spectrum.

#### Photoluminescence II: Phosphorescence

The day I wrote this sentence, I helped my three-year-old daughter put
constellations of glow-in-the-dark stars on the ceiling of her bedroom.
At first, the glow emitted by glow-in-the-dark stickers, plastic, and
paint seems like it might be fluorescent. However, fluorescent items
stop glowing as soon as we turn off the excitation sources, whereas
glow-in-the-dark materials stay lit for several minutes or even hours.
This long-lasting glow is indicative of a process known as
**phosphorescence**. Phosphorescence occurs when the **spin** of an
excited electron changes sign (i.e., from "up" to "down" or vice versa).
Such an electron enters a new manifold of energy states in a process
called **intersystem crossing**. From this new manifold of energy
states, the spin of the electron must go back to its original spin in
order to transition back down to its original ground state. This
transition is quantum mechanically "forbidden." It still happens, but
with a lower probability and thus it takes a long time. Hence why the
stars glow long after the lamp is turned off.

### 8.2.4. Perception of color

Before we begin, it is important to be aware of the limitations of our
own visual system, and not to believe that we are in possession of a
perfect "eyeball spectrometer" (though it is quite good in many
circumstances). In fact, we have three types of color receptive **cone
cells** in our retinas (unless you have some form of colorblindness).
Organisms with these *trichromatic* visual systems have dye molecules in
these light-sensitive cells that respond most strongly to red, green,
and blue light. By mixing different ratios of these colors (see Figure
(8.5), below), it is possible for an RGB display (like the one you are
looking at if you are reading this on a screen) to generate the
perception of any color by triggering these three different cone cells
in the right ratios. For example, a lot of red and slightly less green
would be perceived as yellow centering around 570 nm. A true yellow
light source (like an LED) would excite the same ratios of red and green
cone cells as the "fake" yellow light, and the outcome would be exactly
the same: i.e., you would perceive yellow, even though you do not have a
single cone cell that responds to yellow light.

(Figure 8.5)

The photons that reach our eyes which are involved in the perception of
color have either been transmitted, scattered, or emitted. If you are
reading this on a screen, the photons have been emitted by semiconductor

transmitted. If you are reading this on paper, the light that is
reaching your eyes has been scattered by the white paper and absorbed by

object to appear a certain color, it absorbs every color but the one it
appears, which is reflected. This is a bit of an oversimplification, but
it gets the point across, at least for opaque materials. There are

Finally, light can reach our eyes through the process of direct

monochromatic light source, such as a laser, which emits only at a

Ultimately, the perception of a color by our brain is the result of a
superposition of signals arising from multiple types of color-sensitive
nerve endings that are stimulated in a ratio that depends on the
incoming wavelength. What the brain does with this information is
waaaaay outside the scope of this course. But the bottom line is that we
perceive it as a color.

#### Section 3: Quantum mechanical model for absorption: the particle in a box
There are several models one can use to predict the electronic
transitions and absorption properties of relatively simple absorbers
like organic dyes. The simplest---though it is not simple to any
first-time learner---is the **particle-in-a-box** model. The most common
type of particle-in-a-box is an electron in an energy well with
infinitely hard side walls. Inside the well, the potential energy is
zero. Beyond the walls, the potential energy is infinite. Imagine that
an electron is placed in the well. Remember our discussion of photons as
both particles and waves? It turns out that *every* object can be
treated as both a particle and a wave. That is, even solid, macroscopic
objects have wavelike properties. However, for objects of appreciable
mass, the wavelength is miniscule and the object can be treated as a
particle only. Thus, the wavelike properties of matter typically only
manifest for electrons, protons, atoms, and very small molecules.

The behavior of an electron inside the box can be described by a
**wavefunction**, which is a solution to the **Schrödinger equation**

(Equation 8.2) $$-\frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\frac{d^2\psi(x)}{dx^2}=E\psi(x)$$

where $\hbar$ is Planck's constant divided by 2$\pi$, $m$ is the mass of
the particle (the electron in this case), $\psi(x)$ is the wave
function, $x$ is the horizontal position variable along the box, and
$\frac{d^2\psi(x)}{dx^2}$ is the second derivative of the wave function
with respect to the position.[^8.3.1] The Schrödinger equation is an example
of a **differential equation**, which is a function that is related to
its own derivative. While there are whole courses in "diff-eq" that you
will probably take later in your studies, we can get most of the way
there just by looking at the equation with the sparest knowledge of
first-semester or AP calculus. The question is, what function has the
same form as its second derivative? The answer is sine and cosine

### 8.3.1. Organic dyes and the color of carrots

The particle-in-a-box model can first seem very obscure. What it is it
good for? It turns out that the particle-in-a-box model is most useful
in determining energy *differences* between states. Often, what we care
about most are the gaps between the valence band and the conduction band
of a molecule or a solid. In some (idealized) cases, it is even possible
to get a number that's in the right ballpark of the correct value for a
physical system. Consider the structure of $\beta$-carotene, below
(Figure (8.8)).

(Figure 8.8) 
>>>image(betacarotene.png.0)

$\beta$-Carotene is the structure most commonly associated with the
orange color of carrots, though in pure form it is more red than orange.
The most striking structural feature of $\beta$-carotene is its long
conjugated core (that is, alternating double and single bonds). Such a
structure gives rise to absorption in the visible region of the
electromagnetic spectrum.[^8.3.3] It is actually possible to use the
particle-in-a-box model to predict that $\beta$-carotene absorbs in the
visible region of the spectrum. Furthermore, if we are a little loose
with some of the parameters, we can get it to appear orange.

To start out, we need to know the approximate length of the
$\pi$-conjugated **chromophore**[^8.3.4] and the number of electrons in it.
Let's say a good approximation is 18.5 Å. Looking at the structure in
Figure (8.8), we see that there are 22 carbon atoms involved in the
$\pi$ system. From general chemistry, we know that some number of
**atomic orbitals** give rise to the same number of **molecular
orbitals**. So, we will expect to have 22 total molecular orbitals. An
orbital is a place where electrons live, and it can be defined
mathematically by a wave function, $\psi(x)$. As you may also remember,
each bonding molecular orbital gets two electrons, so the first 11 wave
functions starting with the lowest energy---representing the 11
**bonding orbitals** of $\beta$-carotene---are filled, while the top 11
wave functions---representing the **antibonding orbitals** are empty.
The bonding orbitals can be treated as the valence band, and the
antibonding orbitals can be treated as the conduction band. The **band
gap** is defined as the difference in energy between the **highest
occupied molecular orbital (HOMO)** (i.e., the valence band edge) and
the **lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO)** (i.e., the conduction
band edge). Convince yourself that the difference in energy is given by
the following equation:

(Equation 8.5) $$\Delta E = (n_f^2 - n_i^2)\frac{h^2}{8 m L^2}$$

where $n_i$ is the initial state and $n_f$ is the final state. When the
molecule absorbs a photon, the electron is promoted from $n_i$ to $n_f$.
If these two states correspond to the band edges, then $n_i=11$ and
$n_f=12$. So,

$$\Delta E = (12^2 - 11^2)\frac{h^2}{8 m L^2}$$

$$\Delta E = \frac{23h^2}{8 m L^2}$$

$$\Delta E = \frac{23 \times (6.6 \times 10^{-34} \, \text{Js})^2}{8 (9.1 \times 10^{-31} \, \text{kg})(1.85 \times 10^{-9} \, \text{m})^2}$$

$$\Delta E = \frac{hc}{490 \, \text{nm}}$$


The real bandgap of $\beta$-carotene is closer to 470 nm, but we should
be surprised that this super simple model got as close as it did. After
all, 18.5 Å is not quite the length of the $\pi$ system, however, we
also ignored all of the electrostatic effects of the protons, the fact
that these molecules are twisting and dancing all over the place, and
the fact that the electrons are not truly **delocalized**. That is, in a
real molecule---not the fake construct of a box with infinite
walls---the electrons are not free to occupy any of the length of the
"box" defined by the $\pi$ system.

### 8.3.2. Quantum dots

A quantum dot is a clever nickname for a **semiconductor nanocrystal**.
The moniker "dot" emphasizes the quantization of the energy levels. Just
like the particle in a box, a quantum dot has **quantized**---can only
take on a predefined set of energies---absorption and emission behavior.
Quantum dots can be made of any direct-bandgap semiconductor, but are
often metal chalcogenides, including cadmium selenide (CdSe), cadmium
telluride (CdTe), and lead sulfide (PbS). However, any small
semiconductor particle with quantized energy levels will exhibit
quantum-dot-like behavior. Small platelets of graphene will even
qualify: **graphene quantum dots**.

The energy of absorption and emission in a quantum dot follows the same
qualitative trend as in the particle-in-a-box model: the smaller the
dot, the more confined the electron, the larger the bandgap, and thus
the bluer (higher energy!) the absorption and emission. It is common to
see pretty photographs of fluorescent quantum dots like the drawing in
Figure (8.9), which emphasizes the relationship between particle size
and band gap.

(Figure 8.9) 
>>>image(quantum dot.png.0)

The energy of emission of a quantum dot can be predicted by calculating
its band gap, as determined by

(Equation 8.6)
$$E_{QD} = E_{bulk} + \frac{\hbar^2\pi^2}{2a^2} (\frac{1}{m_e} + \frac{1}{m_h}) - \frac{1.8e^2}{4\pi\epsilon\epsilon_0a}$$

where the first term is the energy of the bandgap of the bulk
semiconductor (i.e., a block of the material of macroscopic extent), the
second term is due to size confinement (i.e., the particle-in-a-box
energy), and the third term is the Coulombic attraction between the
electron and the hole. $\hbar$ is Planck's constant divided by 2$\pi$,
and $a$ is the radius of the quantum dot. The band gap of the quantum

to the particle-in-a-box energy (notice the similarity of the second
term of equation (8.6) to that of equation (8.5)). In this case, $m_e$
and $m_h$ are the masses of the electron and hole.[^8.3.5] Finally, the
energy of the bandgap of the quantum dot is reduced by the (favorable)
attraction between the electron and hole. In fact, the final term in
equation (8.6) looks a lot like Coulomb's law, equation (2.1).

#### Section 2: Scattering, absorption, and nothing
When a photon strikes an object, three things can happen:
**scattering**, **absorption**, and **nothing**. Which of these
eventualities occurs depends on the size, shape, atomic composition, and
various idiosyncracies of the chunk of matter under consideration.

### 8.2.1. Scattering

Scattering is the process of absorption and re-emission of a photon in
rapid succession. In fact, most of the photons that arrive at our
retinas have been scattered by the objects we perceive in our visual
field. Absorption and re-emission occurs by transient[^8.2.1] polarization
of the electron cloud of the atoms that make up an object; when the
electron cloud returns to its unpolarized equilibrium, a photon is
re-emitted. This re-emitted photon is known as the **scattered photon**.

#### Elastic and inelastic scattering

The energy of the scattered photon is either greater than, less than, or
equal to the energy of the incident photon. In the case where the
scattered photon has the same energy as that of the incident photon, the
scattering process is deemed **elastic** or **Rayleigh** scattering.
That is, energy was neither absorbed by the material nor transferred to
the photon as a result of the collision. When the energy is greater than
or less than that of the incident photon, the process is said to be
**inelastic** or **Raman** scattering. That is, energy is either
absorbed by the material or transferred from the material to the photon.
A schematic diagram of the two scattering processes is shown in Figure
(8.2).

(Figure 8.2) 
>>>image(scattering.png.0)

Inelastic scattering---the type of scattering where energy is absorbed
by the material as a result of the collision---is by far the more common
type. In this case, the energy of the scattered photon is less than the
energy of the incident photon (longer wavelength). The "missing" energy
from the incident photon often goes into raising the vibrational energy
of the scatterer. That is, energy gets transferred from the incident
photon to the scatterer, which is initially in a low-energy vibrational
state. The scatterer absorbs some of this energy, knocking it up to a
higher energy vibrational state (i.e., vibrating at a higher frequency).
The downward shift in the energy of the scattered photon with respect to
that of the incident photon is called a **Stokes shift**, which just
means that the scattered photon has less energy than the incident
photon. You may also see the word **red shift** or the super jargony
word ***bathochromic* shift**.

#### Vibrational spectroscopy: Infrared and Raman

Sometimes, a scatterer is already in a higher (excited) vibrational
state, and in the process of collision with the incoming photon, this
extra energy is transferred to the scattered photon. The scattered
photon thus has increased energy (shorter wavelength) compared to the
energy of the incident photon. The shift in wavelength of the scattered
photon relative to the incident photon is called an **anti-Stokes**
shift, a **blue shift**, or a ***hypsochromic* shift**. Vibrational
transitions, which are are usually in the infrared region of the EM
spectrum, can be observed directly by infrared absorption
spectroscopy[^8.2.2] or indirectly upon irradiation with a laser of a
visible wavelength, by **Raman spectroscopy**. In this modality, the
energy of the vibrational transition is equal to the difference in
energy between the incident and scattered light.[^8.2.3]

The differences in energy between incident and scattered or emitted
photons is the basis of the field of **spectroscopy**. It is often
possible to reveal something about the construction of molecules and the
composition of matter by analyzing the *spectra* produced by
light-matter interactions. These spectra can act as fingerprints unique
to the interaction taking place, and like detectives at the scene of a
crime, we can use spectroscopy help identify the matter of interest. We
will touch on electronic absorption (ultraviolet-visible) and
fluorescence spectroscopy in later sections in this chapter.

### 8.2.2. Absorption due to the movement of electrons

As we hinted in the discussion of scattering, it is common for some or
all of the energy of an incident photon to be absorbed by the material
or molecule. We touched on changes in vibrational energy levels that can
occur upon absorption, but such differences usually take place in the
infrared spectrum. For optoelectronic applications (e.g., solar cells
and display panels), we are often more interested in those that occur in
the visible range of the EM spectrum. The molecular basis for visible
absorption usually involves promotion of electrons from the **conduction
band** or **bonding orbitals** to the **valence band** or **antibonding
orbitals**. These transitions are interesting because they can indicate
chemical activity such as bond breakage or photon-driven charge
separation in solar cells. In Figure (8.3), we see a diagram of the band
energies for a generic material that absorbs light in the visible region
of the EM spectrum (i.e., a dye molecule, a semiconductor, or a quantum
dot).

(Figure 8.3) 
>>>image(orbitals.png.0)

You might ask why, if the band gap energy has a specific value (say, 2.5
electron volts), the absorption spectrum is a broad hump and not a sharp
vertical line. Indeed, for a completely isolated, single molecule at a
temperature of absolute zero, one might obtain a single vertical line.
The reason this does not happen in the real world is that the gap
between the valence and conduction bands is a measure of the gap between
the **frontiers** or **edges** of these bands. When a molecule is in
solution and in van der Waals contact with nearby molecules, the energy
levels become blurry. That is, there are many energy states above and
below these levels to and from which electrons can be excited by an
incoming photon. The function that describes the distribution of energy
levels is called the **density of states**. It is this interplay of
light and electronic energy levels---combined with the phenomena in
scattering---that gives rise to the perception of color.

### 8.2.3. Emission: Fluorescence and Phosphorescence

Suppose a molecule absorbs a photon, and an electron that was initially
in the ground state (say at the valence band edge) gets promoted to a
higher energy level (say the conduction band edge). The potential energy
of the electron is now substantially greater than it was before, and
this is an unstable situation. The electron will tend to return to its
ground state, and can do so in a number of ways. For example, it can
collide with some other molecules, which take on some of the energy as
translational motion, and the electron eventually makes its way back to
the valence band. This process is called **non-radiative
recombination**[^8.2.4]. Alternatively, the electron can transfer its energy
to another molecule, whose electron gets promoted, while the electron of
the original molecule returns to its ground state. This type of energy
transfer can be mediated by a photon---i.e., emitted by the first
molecule and absorbed by the second---or it can occur through space,
without the emission of a photon. When the non-photon process occurs, it
is called **Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET)**, and tends to
occur when the emission spectrum of the first molecule overlaps with the
absorption spectrum of the second. Finally, the excited electron may
decay to the ground state by emitting a photon similar, but not usually
identical,[^8.2.5] to the band gap in two related processes known as
*fluorescence* and *phosphorescence*.

#### Photoluminescence I: Fluorescence

If you have ever been in a room with a black light (i.e., near-visible,
UV-A light) or pointed one at various objects to see if anything glows,
that glowing is a type of **photoluminescence**[^8.2.6] called
**fluorescence**. In general, fluorescence occurs when high-energy light
is absorbed and re-emitted by a molecule or material as lower-energy
light. To see why this is, consider Figure (8.4) shown below.

(Figure 8.4) 
>>>image(thermalization.png.0)

The band gap has a specific energy and it is true that photons with
energies *below* the band gap do not get absorbed. However, we know that
photons with energies *above* than the band gap get absorbed all the
time. When an electron gets excited by such a high-energy photon, where
does it go? The answer is that it gets promoted to one of the energy
levels above the band edge with a probability based on the **density of
states**.[^8.2.7] Once the electron is in this higher-energy state, it
quickly transitions down to the band edge by releasing its energy into
the bulk material (or solution) as heat. This process, known as
**thermalization**, ensures that the starting point for every
fluorescent process starts with the electron at the bottom of the
conduction band. While these electrons may return to the energy level
exactly at the edge of the valence band, it is more likely that they too
will find a band with a lower energy than the band edge. Again, this
process is determined by the density of states, this time below the band
edge. These processes ensure that the energy of the absorption spectrum
for a molecule or material is centered in a range higher than that of
the fluorescence spectrum.

#### Photoluminescence II: Phosphorescence

The day I wrote this sentence, I helped my three-year-old daughter put
constellations of glow-in-the-dark stars on the ceiling of her bedroom.
At first, the glow emitted by glow-in-the-dark stickers, plastic, and
paint seems like it might be fluorescent. However, fluorescent items
stop glowing as soon as we turn off the excitation sources, whereas
glow-in-the-dark materials stay lit for several minutes or even hours.
This long-lasting glow is indicative of a process known as
**phosphorescence**. Phosphorescence occurs when the **spin** of an
excited electron changes sign (i.e., from "up" to "down" or vice versa).
Such an electron enters a new manifold of energy states in a process
called **intersystem crossing**. From this new manifold of energy
states, the spin of the electron must go back to its original spin in
order to transition back down to its original ground state. This
transition is quantum mechanically "forbidden." It still happens, but
with a lower probability and thus it takes a long time. Hence why the
stars glow long after the lamp is turned off.

### 8.2.4. Perception of color

Before we begin, it is important to be aware of the limitations of our
own visual system, and not to believe that we are in possession of a
perfect "eyeball spectrometer" (though it is quite good in many
circumstances). In fact, we have three types of color receptive **cone
cells** in our retinas (unless you have some form of colorblindness).
Organisms with these *trichromatic* visual systems have dye molecules in
these light-sensitive cells that respond most strongly to red, green,
and blue light. By mixing different ratios of these colors (see Figure
(8.5), below), it is possible for an RGB display (like the one you are
looking at if you are reading this on a screen) to generate the
perception of any color by triggering these three different cone cells
in the right ratios. For example, a lot of red and slightly less green
would be perceived as yellow centering around 570 nm. A true yellow
light source (like an LED) would excite the same ratios of red and green
cone cells as the "fake" yellow light, and the outcome would be exactly
the same: i.e., you would perceive yellow, even though you do not have a
single cone cell that responds to yellow light.

(Figure 8.5)

The photons that reach our eyes which are involved in the perception of
color have either been transmitted, scattered, or emitted. If you are
reading this on a screen, the photons have been emitted by semiconductor
light emitting devices behind the colored pixels, through which they are
transmitted. If you are reading this on paper, the light that is
reaching your eyes has been scattered by the white paper and absorbed by
the black ink.[^8.2.8] You may remember from elementary school that for an
object to appear a certain color, it absorbs every color but the one it
appears, which is reflected. This is a bit of an oversimplification, but
it gets the point across, at least for opaque materials. There are
actually a few ways that an object produces color when illuminated with

(Figure 8.6)

Finally, light can reach our eyes through the process of direct

monochromatic light source, such as a laser, which emits only at a

superposition of signals arising from multiple types of color-sensitive
nerve endings that are stimulated in a ratio that depends on the
incoming wavelength. What the brain does with this information is

#### Section 1: Properties of light
Everything you see around you is ultimately the result of light waves
interacting with molecular structures, nanostructures, and
surfaces---i.e., **light-matter interactions**. These light waves engage
the matter in various ways, and some of them are conveyed back to you to
create an image on your retina. The way that light waves interact with
atoms and molecules, and then travel to reach your retina, involves
several different processes. Since visible light occupies the range of
wavelengths from around 400-700 nm, these processes are by definition
mediated on the nanoscale. Thus, the atomic and molecular structure,
along with the nanoscale geometry of matter, determine what happens when
a **photon** of light strikes the object.[^8.1.1] For example, the photon
may be absorbed and its energy could be transferred to an electron. In
another scenario, the photon may cause the conduction electrons in a
solid to be briefly polarized and then return to equilibrium by
re-emitting a photon. Alternatively, nothing may happen. These
interactions between light and matter are responsible for much of our
observed, day-to-day experience. Moreover, they also enable myriad
applications, from solar cells to displays, which will be discussed in
the next chapter. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

Electromagnetic radiation consists of propagating, oscillating
**electric** and **magnetic fields** oriented 90 $^{\circ}$ to each
other. The **electromagnetic spectrum**, Figure (8.1), is a linear range
of energies, which are often expressed in terms of either frequency or

(6.626$\times10^{-34}\text{ J s or J per Hz}$, $\nu$ is the frequency in
Hz (s$^{-1}$), $c$ is the speed of light in a vacuum, and $\lambda$ is
the wavelength.

### 8.1.1. Wave-particle duality

Electromagnetic waves have properties of both waves and particles. For
example, light diffracts like a wave, meaning that it bends around
corners and interferes with itself when passing through slits. However,
it also reflects off of objects like the way that billiard balls bounce
off of objects. Moreover, light is made of up small, quantized bits of
energy. These single particles of light are called **photons**[^8.1.3]
Wave-particle duality emerges when considering the fact that single
photons can also interfere with themselves. This property was
demonstrated using a now classic setup called **Young's double-slit
experiment**. When shining a light through two closely spaced slits
(openings) to a projection screen, one obtains a diffraction pattern of
many minima and maxima in light intensity.[^8.1.4] Later, it was determined
that the same pattern is obtained even when the source only emits a
single photon at a time (which produces a single blip on the screen or
detector) if the photon counts are all added up after the experiment
runs for a while. So, a single photon is passing through the slits,
interfering with itself, and yet producing a single spot on the
detector! Diffraction is also the basis of **X-ray crystallography**,
discussed in Chapter 14.

### 8.1.2. Types of EM radiation

Visible light comprises only a small region of the EM spectrum, from
400-700 nm. Smaller wavelengths---higher energies---are ultraviolet,
then X-rays, then gamma ($\gamma$) rays. Larger wavelengths---lower
energies---are infrared (IR), then microwaves, then radio waves (Figure
(8.1)). Each range of wavelengths interacts with matter at a different
scale. For example, gamma rays are associated with nuclear reactions.
X-rays are associated with nuclear reactions and the differences in
energy between electrons at the surface of an atom and those at the
core. Ultraviolet radiation is absorbed by electrons involved in bonds
extending across a few atoms, while visible light is absorbed by
electrons delocalized across many atoms. IR radiation can excite
vibrational and rotational motions in molecules, while microwaves can
excite motion in molecules having permanent dipoles. Radio waves
interact with larger (centimeter to meter scale) metallic structures.
The use of EM radiation to probe aspects of the structure of
matter---i.e., **spectroscopy**---is covered in Chapter 14.

or less than that of the incident photon, the process is said to be
**inelastic** or **Raman** scattering. That is, energy is either
absorbed by the material or transferred from the material to the photon.

Inelastic scattering---the type of scattering where energy is absorbed
by the material as a result of the collision---is by far the more common
type. In this case, the energy of the scattered photon is less than the
energy of the incident photon (longer wavelength). The "missing" energy
from the incident photon often goes into raising the vibrational energy
of the scatterer. That is, energy gets transferred from the incident
photon to the scatterer, which is initially in a low-energy vibrational
state. The scatterer absorbs some of this energy, knocking it up to a
higher energy vibrational state (i.e., vibrating at a higher frequency).
The downward shift in the energy of the scattered photon with respect to
that of the incident photon is called a **Stokes shift**, which just
means that the scattered photon has less energy than the incident
photon. You may also see the word **red shift** or the super jargony
word ***bathochromic* shift**.

#### Vibrational spectroscopy: Infrared and Raman

Sometimes, a scatterer is already in a higher (excited) vibrational
state, and in the process of collision with the incoming photon, this
extra energy is transferred to the scattered photon. The scattered
photon thus has increased energy (shorter wavelength) compared to the
energy of the incident photon. The shift in wavelength of the scattered
photon relative to the incident photon is called an **anti-Stokes**
shift, a **blue shift**, or a ***hypsochromic* shift**. Vibrational
transitions, which are are usually in the infrared region of the EM
spectrum, can be observed directly by infrared absorption
spectroscopy[^8.2.2] or indirectly upon irradiation with a laser of a
visible wavelength, by **Raman spectroscopy**. In this modality, the
energy of the vibrational transition is equal to the difference in
energy between the incident and scattered light.[^8.2.3]

The differences in energy between incident and scattered or emitted
photons is the basis of the field of **spectroscopy**. It is often
possible to reveal something about the construction of molecules and the
composition of matter by analyzing the *spectra* produced by
light-matter interactions. These spectra can act as fingerprints unique
to the interaction taking place, and like detectives at the scene of a
crime, we can use spectroscopy help identify the matter of interest. We
will touch on electronic absorption (ultraviolet-visible) and
fluorescence spectroscopy in later sections in this chapter.

### 8.2.2. Absorption due to the movement of electrons

As we hinted in the discussion of scattering, it is common for some or
all of the energy of an incident photon to be absorbed by the material
or molecule. We touched on changes in vibrational energy levels that can
occur upon absorption, but such differences usually take place in the
infrared spectrum. For optoelectronic applications (e.g., solar cells
and display panels), we are often more interested in those that occur in
the visible range of the EM spectrum. The molecular basis for visible
absorption usually involves promotion of electrons from the **conduction
band** or **bonding orbitals** to the **valence band** or **antibonding
orbitals**. These transitions are interesting because they can indicate
chemical activity such as bond breakage or photon-driven charge
separation in solar cells. In Figure (8.3), we see a diagram of the band
energies for a generic material that absorbs light in the visible region
of the EM spectrum (i.e., a dye molecule, a semiconductor, or a quantum
dot).

(Figure 8.3) 
>>>image(orbitals.png.0)

You might ask why, if the band gap energy has a specific value (say, 2.5
electron volts), the absorption spectrum is a broad hump and not a sharp
vertical line. Indeed, for a completely isolated, single molecule at a
temperature of absolute zero, one might obtain a single vertical line.
The reason this does not happen in the real world is that the gap
between the valence and conduction bands is a measure of the gap between
the **frontiers** or **edges** of these bands. When a molecule is in
solution and in van der Waals contact with nearby molecules, the energy
levels become blurry. That is, there are many energy states above and
below these levels to and from which electrons can be excited by an
incoming photon. The function that describes the distribution of energy
levels is called the **density of states**. It is this interplay of
light and electronic energy levels---combined with the phenomena in
scattering---that gives rise to the perception of color.

### 8.2.3. Emission: Fluorescence and Phosphorescence

Suppose a molecule absorbs a photon, and an electron that was initially
in the ground state (say at the valence band edge) gets promoted to a
higher energy level (say the conduction band edge). The potential energy
of the electron is now substantially greater than it was before, and
this is an unstable situation. The electron will tend to return to its
ground state, and can do so in a number of ways. For example, it can
collide with some other molecules, which take on some of the energy as
translational motion, and the electron eventually makes its way back to
the valence band. This process is called **non-radiative
recombination**[^8.2.4]. Alternatively, the electron can transfer its energy
to another molecule, whose electron gets promoted, while the electron of
the original molecule returns to its ground state. This type of energy
transfer can be mediated by a photon---i.e., emitted by the first
molecule and absorbed by the second---or it can occur through space,
without the emission of a photon. When the non-photon process occurs, it
is called **Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET)**, and tends to
occur when the emission spectrum of the first molecule overlaps with the
absorption spectrum of the second. Finally, the excited electron may
decay to the ground state by emitting a photon similar, but not usually
identical,[^8.2.5] to the band gap in two related processes known as
*fluorescence* and *phosphorescence*.

#### Photoluminescence I: Fluorescence

If you have ever been in a room with a black light (i.e., near-visible,
UV-A light) or pointed one at various objects to see if anything glows,
that glowing is a type of **photoluminescence**[^8.2.6] called
**fluorescence**. In general, fluorescence occurs when high-energy light
is absorbed and re-emitted by a molecule or material as lower-energy
light. To see why this is, consider Figure (8.4) shown below.

(Figure 8.4) 
>>>image(thermalization.png.0)

The band gap has a specific energy and it is true that photons with
energies *below* the band gap do not get absorbed. However, we know that
photons with energies *above* than the band gap get absorbed all the
time. When an electron gets excited by such a high-energy photon, where
does it go? The answer is that it gets promoted to one of the energy
levels above the band edge with a probability based on the **density of
states**.[^8.2.7] Once the electron is in this higher-energy state, it
quickly transitions down to the band edge by releasing its energy into
the bulk material (or solution) as heat. This process, known as
**thermalization**, ensures that the starting point for every
fluorescent process starts with the electron at the bottom of the
conduction band. While these electrons may return to the energy level
exactly at the edge of the valence band, it is more likely that they too
will find a band with a lower energy than the band edge. Again, this
process is determined by the density of states, this time below the band
edge. These processes ensure that the energy of the absorption spectrum
for a molecule or material is centered in a range higher than that of
the fluorescence spectrum.

#### Photoluminescence II: Phosphorescence

The day I wrote this sentence, I helped my three-year-old daughter put
constellations of glow-in-the-dark stars on the ceiling of her bedroom.
At first, the glow emitted by glow-in-the-dark stickers, plastic, and
paint seems like it might be fluorescent. However, fluorescent items
stop glowing as soon as we turn off the excitation sources, whereas
glow-in-the-dark materials stay lit for several minutes or even hours.
This long-lasting glow is indicative of a process known as
**phosphorescence**. Phosphorescence occurs when the **spin** of an
excited electron changes sign (i.e., from "up" to "down" or vice versa).
Such an electron enters a new manifold of energy states in a process
called **intersystem crossing**. From this new manifold of energy
states, the spin of the electron must go back to its original spin in
order to transition back down to its original ground state. This
transition is quantum mechanically "forbidden." It still happens, but
with a lower probability and thus it takes a long time. Hence why the
stars glow long after the lamp is turned off.

### 8.2.4. Perception of color

Before we begin, it is important to be aware of the limitations of our
own visual system, and not to believe that we are in possession of a
perfect "eyeball spectrometer" (though it is quite good in many
circumstances). In fact, we have three types of color receptive **cone
cells** in our retinas (unless you have some form of colorblindness).
Organisms with these *trichromatic* visual systems have dye molecules in
these light-sensitive cells that respond most strongly to red, green,
and blue light. By mixing different ratios of these colors (see Figure

looking at if you are reading this on a screen) to generate the
perception of any color by triggering these three different cone cells
in the right ratios. For example, a lot of red and slightly less green
would be perceived as yellow centering around 570 nm. A true yellow
light source (like an LED) would excite the same ratios of red and green
cone cells as the "fake" yellow light, and the outcome would be exactly

single cone cell that responds to yellow light.

#### Section 3: Quantum mechanical model for absorption: the particle in a box
There are several models one can use to predict the electronic
transitions and absorption properties of relatively simple absorbers
like organic dyes. The simplest---though it is not simple to any
first-time learner---is the **particle-in-a-box** model. The most common
type of particle-in-a-box is an electron in an energy well with
infinitely hard side walls. Inside the well, the potential energy is
zero. Beyond the walls, the potential energy is infinite. Imagine that
an electron is placed in the well. Remember our discussion of photons as
both particles and waves? It turns out that *every* object can be
treated as both a particle and a wave. That is, even solid, macroscopic
objects have wavelike properties. However, for objects of appreciable
mass, the wavelength is miniscule and the object can be treated as a
particle only. Thus, the wavelike properties of matter typically only
manifest for electrons, protons, atoms, and very small molecules.

The behavior of an electron inside the box can be described by a
**wavefunction**, which is a solution to the **Schrödinger equation**

(Equation 8.2) $$-\frac{\hbar^2}{2m}\frac{d^2\psi(x)}{dx^2}=E\psi(x)$$

where $\hbar$ is Planck's constant divided by 2$\pi$, $m$ is the mass of
the particle (the electron in this case), $\psi(x)$ is the wave
function, $x$ is the horizontal position variable along the box, and
$\frac{d^2\psi(x)}{dx^2}$ is the second derivative of the wave function
with respect to the position.[^8.3.1] The Schrödinger equation is an example
of a **differential equation**, which is a function that is related to
its own derivative. While there are whole courses in "diff-eq" that you
will probably take later in your studies, we can get most of the way
there just by looking at the equation with the sparest knowledge of
first-semester or AP calculus. The question is, what function has the
same form as its second derivative? The answer is sine and cosine
functions! After some guessing and checking, one can come up with the
following

(Equation 8.3) $$\psi_n(x)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{L}}\sin{\frac{n\pi x}{L}}$$

where the index $n$ is an integer $\geq$ 1. Plugging this solution back
into equation (8.2), we get an expression for the energy

(Equation 8.4) $$E_n=\frac{h^2n^2}{8mL^2}$$

where $E_n$ is the energy of the $n^{th}$ energy level. The shapes of
the wave functions and the energies of the electrons occupying these
states only have physical meaning in the most contrived, idealized
scenarios. Nevertheless, wave functions can be obtained for a number of
potentials, such as spherical ones for atoms.

Figure (8.7) below shows the shapes of the wave functions for $n=1$,
termed the **ground state**, $n=2$, termed the **first excited state**,
and $n=3$, the **second excited state**.[^8.3.2] In these diagrams, the wave
function $\psi(x)$ is the **probability amplitude**; it shows the shape
of the wave function, and in particular the phases (i.e., above and
below an imaginary horizontal line separating the "positive" and
"negative" regions of the function). The square of this function,
$|\psi(x)|^2$, is the **probability density**, which is positive (above
the horizontal line) everywhere. That is, the function which shows where
you are most likely to find the electron within the box. This function
integrates to 1, since that is the probability of finding the electron
somewhere in the box.

(Figure 8.7)
